101.text: For the last 28 years, I've been documenting

104.text: indigenous cultures in more than 70 countries

107.text: on six continents, and in 2009 I had the great honor

111.text: of being the sole exhibitor at the Vancouver Peace Summit.

115.text: Amongst all the astonishing people I met there,

119.text: I met a supporter of Free the Slaves, an NGO

122.text: dedicated to eradicating modern day slavery.

127.text: We started talking about slavery, and really,

133.text: for I had certainly known it existed in the world,

136.text: but not to such a degree.

139.text: After we finished talking, I felt so horrible

143.text: and honestly ashamed at my own lack of knowledge

146.text: of this atrocity in my own lifetime, and I thought,

150.text: if I don't know, how many other people don't know?

155.text: It started burning a hole in my stomach, so within weeks,

158.text: I flew down to Los Angeles to meet with the director

161.text: of Free the Slaves and offer them my help.

165.text: Thus began my journey into modern day slavery.

169.text: Oddly, I had been to many of these places before.

172.text: Some I even considered like my second home.

176.text: But this time, I would see the skeletons hidden in the closet.
